comments.commentBody: What's next:  sometimes fries, sometimes a soda.

I read this with some expectation of being enlightened but it appears to just stop, right in the middle. After being told filet o fish worked with one person, I felt I was left hanging alone at the end of the pier.
What next?

To MNW ~ Thank you. Your reasoning regarding the 'moderators' being computer rather than human makes sense. But the NYT Picks must have some humans reading. Yes?
I've had the green check since late 2012 but began posting comments much earlier, whenever it was that the NYT opened articles to comments. I remember posting frequently to Bob Herbert's op-eds and those were the comments of mine that often garnered many recommendations.
Sometime in 2012, the NYT invited me to become a green check commenter(not their terminology). Usually the check gets one's comment posted almost immediately, no other perks.
You know it's regardless, right? "Irregardless' isn't even ironic any longer.

Commenters here are giving Hillary a pass because she is a woman that they would never do for a man when reviewing the state of the Middle East after her tenure as Secretary of State and this article's detailed characterization of her as a hawk. If Kissinger were a woman, they would have supported her/him too. As long as you're financially comfortable and have no family in harm's way, then you're okay with a neoliberal nation-building hawk. The shameless Clintons  leading the shameless upper class liberati. Through the eye of a needle!

Thanks, Yes, an agenda! In not sure which article you mean, but I've read & heard so much, I forget where it is sometimes. Today I received the NYT mag, & HRC is THE focus on cover! It's so hi profile, at least it's a nice picture of our most hawkish candidate!
Many of Hillary's supporters show their own shallow grasp of foreign policy if they think her alliance with hawks including Henry Kissinger will somehow help America's position in world affairs.

This article confirms the long history of Clinton in supporting regime change and the use of the military to solve problems. If elected she is a danger to the United States and in many ways, as noted in the article, will run to the right of Trump on military intervention. Trump has indicated he "has not even started on Hillary yet" and her consistent hawkish positions and terrible public perception may pose real dangers to the Democrats if she runs. Worst, if she is elected, we may find the United States involved in another senseless war.   One legislator, who worked with Clinton for years, noted  that there “hasn’t been a military engagement that Hillary has not been for in the past 20 years.” Clinton’s saber-rattling history and positions should give the voters and Democrats very serious concerns.
"if indicted by the Justice Department"....Far more likely she will be indicted for Benghazi. That was so much more serious there were 34 Congressional hearings.

Not that unusual. In the 80s, the praise that Ronald Reagan bestowed on Margaret Thatcher for turning the economy of the UK around during that period was essentially built on one primary industry, arms and ultimately, constant wars provoked around the world to build and maintain that industry. The UK is now one of the top five seller of military equipment in the world, just a wonderful legacy for Thatcher that few people actually know about.

Dwight D. Eisenhowers last speech as President is probably more applicable today than it ever was in which he stated /Beware the military Industrial Complex/. Of her many influential donors over the years, I am sure Hillary has received substantial funds from them as well.

Here we go again. Another liberal Republican masquerading as a Democrat. Obama has said that in a different time he might have been a liberal Republican. Will history repeat itself as farce or tragedy?

But unbeknownst to many, Hillary has a very effective plan to pull us out of our downward economic spiral. No, it's not everyone hugging.

It's war.

Hillary Clinton is a dangerous cocktail. She is fueled by personal ambition using foreign policy to achieve these ends. As the article shows, along with her personal entourage of hawk generals antithetical to the administration's foreign policy objectives, she single-handedly derailed President Obama's very intelligently put-together decisions and achievements with respect to this region, embroiling our nation and others in a scenario even more difficult to extricate & resolve.

Senator Sanders has great support from American troops and veterans based on his record and achievements in Congress. He is also endorsed by the largest U.S. peace organization, Peace Action, their 1st Presidential candidate endorsement in 25 years. He has integrity, a characteristic clearly foreign to Clinton's psyche.

Former President Jimmy Carter, who is also a Nobel Peace Prize winner for his work with the Carter Center, straightforwardly said that Hillary Clinton did very little for peace during her time in the State Department. That, current U.S. Sec of State John Kerry has done much more to advance those aims.

Clinton shoots from the belt, she's highly arrogant, & she's taking too much money from interests antithetical to the American People and the USA. She even used her State Department position to swap 165 billion dollars in arms to foreign governments contributing to their bogus "foundation." The Saudis & UAE - grave human rights offenders, among her Presidential campaign contributors.
If you are correct, we should elect men to save the peace.

Oh yeah, confident in her capacity to make the most prudent decisions on both domestic and foreign policy...? As in Afghanistan, Iraq, Libya, Benghazi, Syria? Look, had Hillary won in 2008 instead of Barack Iran would be like Iraq today and Ukraine a smoldering ruin in a US-Russia standoff, or worse.
Carol...thank you for volunteering to be the maid of honor at the wedding.

Thank you for reminding me about Honduras. I remembered hearing that our people were arguing whether it was a coup or not, but it kind of breezed by, not even Fox News said much about it. Thanks to you, I found a good article in Huff Post. Like you said, Too bad the US didn't follow up. This explains why NYT had a recent teeny article about US troops in Honduras helping with gang control. I wish we would focus more on violence in this hemisphere. This even made me feel bad for all the kids sneaking in. While our family leans Republican, we're ok with the Clintons if need be. Again, I do agree with several comments re where was our president during these skirmishes? She is not the President, & as per the article, it doesn't sound like she had the power to knock something over if his highness didn't agree.
Based on her history she has more testosterone than many men.  She sure feels scary to me.

Speak for the women in your own life. Neither I nor any of my female friends growing up in blue-collar Philadelphia in the 1950s were taught any such thing. Could you be any more insulting? What we *were* taught was that we had better learn how to support ourselves and not depend on anybody else to do it, including our future husbands.
Partly because she didn't read the intelligence briefings, as she's admitted. One assumes she was too busy beginning work on her Goldman Sachs orations.
Your right, I mean she might get run over by by a truck or slip and fall in the bath tub.

Always be thorough in assessing the threat.
The evaluation of the threat is utmost in defining the solution.
I suggest you take your "CLINTON BLINDERs" off and reread the article before you vote.  She has been a HAWK for years!!
I think one sure sign of a HAWK is a big interest in the military!

That is simply pitiful, Joe..
Why should I vote for her..
Because you "hope" she learned something?

I am a registered Democrat and am determined to vote for someone in November. My father was a Socialist labor-union organizer in the 1930s, and so I have a fundamental disdain for hawks in pterodactyl's clothing. She will not get my vote, no way, no how. Anyone but Hillary, and I mean that.

The problem with the red line in Syria was mostly that it was drawn in the first place.  Once it was crossed we were all lucky that Obama made an agreement to get most of the chemical weapons out of Syria without a war.  Then we were even luckier that Obama was able to come to a decent agreement with Iran on nuclear weapons.  The objective wasn't to make Netanyahu happy or turn Iran into a democracy, it was to prevent a regional war in the Middle East.  I think it worked, and we should be grateful to Obama and everyone who helped bring this about.

It's called realpolitik. The lady has it in spades.

And it's what we need in the White House. Not that President Obama has been a good leader of foreign policy initiatives such as Iran and Cuba, but he's also made mistakes that have cost us credibility. Think of the red line in Syria.

With Clinton, no one will doubt her resolve. Absolutely no one.
